## Why polarization?

Unlike TT:
* Direct probe of last scattering: polarization doesn’t change with time
  * TT spectrum prone to late-time effects like potential decay (SW, ISW)
* Spin-2 field (will get back to in a sec): Inherently contains more information
  * Different sources (SVT) create different polarization patterns: allow you to break down and identify the different sources in the early universe

## How to get polarization?

Thomson scattering preferentially scatters into plane perpendicular to $\hat{\epsilon}$
\begin{align}
\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega} = \frac{3\sigma_T}{8\pi} \left|\hat{\epsilon} \cdot \hat{\epsilon}' \right| = \frac{3\sigma_T}{8\pi} \sin^2\theta
\end{align} (can be shown by differentiating the Larmor formula and dividing by $\langle S\rangle = (c/8\pi)E_0^2$).

If you set up a quadrupole, then hot and cold spots line up to give linear polarization.

## How to describe polarization?

Stokes parameters:
* $I$: total intensity
* $Q$: linear polarization (N–S, E–W)
* $U$: linear polarization (45°: NE–SW, NW–SE)
* $V$: circular polarization

Thomson scattering does not produce circular polarization, so no $V$.

Notice that a sign flip in temperature (hot $\leftrightarrow$ cold) means a flip in sign. What this creates is a **spin-2 field**: $Q$ and $U$ rotate into one another in a rotation
\begin{align}
\begin{pmatrix}Q'\\U'\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}\cos 2\psi & \sin 2\psi \\ -\sin 2\psi & \cos 2\psi\end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}Q\\U\end{pmatrix}
\end{align} (the 2 reflects the spin-2 nature). _[Draw example on board]_

By contrast, temperature is **spin-0** because it is invariant under rotations. This gives it two advantages:
* coordinate system-independent
  * don’t have to worry about every experiment having different coordinates
* easier math

**WE WANT TO WORK WITH SPIN-0 FIELDS!** How do we get it?

Start with the spherical harmonic expansions:
\begin{align}
T(\mathbf{\hat{n}}) &= \sum_{\ell m} a_{\ell m}^\text{T} Y_\ell^m (\mathbf{\hat{n}}) \\
(Q \pm iU)(\mathbf{\hat{n}}) &= \sum_{\ell m} a_{\pm 2,\ell m} \,{}_{\pm 2}Y_\ell^m(\mathbf{\hat{n}})
\end{align}

Define
\begin{align}
a_{\ell,m}^\text{E} &= -\frac{1}{2}(a_{2,\ell m} + a_{-2,\ell m}) \\
a_{\ell,m}^\text{B} &= -\frac{1}{2i}(a_{2,\ell m} - a_{-2,\ell m})
\end{align} combining spin $+2$ and $-2$ quantities gives spin 0. We get new spin-0 fields:
\begin{align}
E(\mathbf{\hat{n}}) &= \sum_{\ell m} a_{\ell m}^\text{E} Y_\ell^m (\mathbf{\hat{n}}) \\
B(\mathbf{\hat{n}}) &= \sum_{\ell m} a_{\ell m}^\text{B} Y_\ell^m (\mathbf{\hat{n}}). \\
\end{align}

Reason why they are called $E$ and $B$ are in analogy with EM:
* $\nabla \times E = 0$ and $\nabla \cdot B = 0$
* Also reason why they are called grad ($E = \nabla \phi$) and curl ($B = \nabla \times A$) fields

I think the most natural way to understand them is their parity. It turns out that
* $E$ has EVEN parity (same after LR flipping)
* $B$ has ODD parity (rotated 180° after flipping)

Reason why parity is important is because **different polarization sources produce patterns that differ in parity**.

## Sources of polarization

Because polarization is spin-2, it is described by a rank-2 tensor, which has the unique property that it can be decomposed into SVT components (can’t do this for other ranks). 

Things that can create a temperature quadrupole:

**Scalar:** density perturbations

**Vector:** vorticity in cosmological fluid

**Tensor:** gravitational waves

_[show the patterns]_

So by looking at the ratios of E and B-modes produced, we can learn about these sources in the early universe.
* $E \gg B$: scalars dominant
* ~~$E \ll B$: vectors dominant~~
* $E \sim B$: tensors dominant

As it turns out, vectors get damped out by the expanding universe, so they are negligible.

Okay, so we now know how it works, let’s do some science with it!

## Uses of polarization

As I alluded to at the beginning, the temperature spectrum is prone to late-time effects. In particular, the amplitude of the TT spectrum is damped by reionization:
\begin{align}
C_\ell^{TT} \sim \Delta T^2 \sim A_s e^{-2\tau}
\end{align} i.e., we don’t know if the power was originally low or whether it was damped out. **If we can find out the optical depth of the universe, we break this degeneracy.**

This is where E-modes come in. It turns out reionization itself generates new polarization because there’s now a whole bunch of free electrons floating around. But because reionization happened so late (500 Myr after BB), the new polarization is generated at angular scales of $\ell < 10$ (horizon at last scattering is $\ell \sim 180$).

_[show reionization bump]_

Earlier reionization means wider and taller peak:
* $n_e$ was larger (scales as $a^{-3}$)
* reaches smaller angular scales (larger $\ell$)

And $n_e$ increases $\Rightarrow \tau$ increases because $\tau = \int n_e \sigma_T \,\mathrm{d}s$.

## How much polarization is there?

If it’s so useful, why don’t everybody go out and measure E-modes? **BECAUSE IT’S HARD!**

### Example of reionization

Current age of universe: 13.8 Gyr = $5\times 10^{17}$ seconds
Mean free time for CMB photon: $1/(n_e(a) \sigma_T c) \sim 2 \times 10^{20} a^3$ seconds
* At end of reionization: $z \sim 5$, $a = 0.2$, age $\sim 4 \times 10^{16}$ seconds
  * $t_\text{mfp} \sim 2 \times 10^{18}$ seconds
  * If universe froze at this time, 25% chance of scattering

At best, there is a 25% chance of scattering after reionization, so the anticipated signal power is at best 25% of the temperature anisotropy
\begin{align}
\frac{\Delta T}{T} \times 25\% \sim \mathcal{O}(1 \,\mathrm{\mu K}).
\end{align} This is further complicated by the fact that polarization detectors have a $\sqrt{2}$ times greater noise than temperature detectors.
